section.title: Modal verbs of obligation and prohibition
section.sectiontitle: Use must and have to for obligation. We often use have to + verb for rules. We often use must + verb (without to) when the obligation comes from the speaker.
section.text1a: You have to have a passport to enter the US.
section.text2a: I must call John. We haven't spoken for months.
section.text3a: You mustn't fight in the classroom.
section.text4a: Books must be returned by six o'clock.

section.title: Modal verbs of obligation and prohibition
section.sectiontitle: Use don't have to for absence of obligation. Don't have to + verb means we have a choice, or that something is not necessary.
section.text1a: I don't have to work on Sundays, but I can if I want to.
section.text2a: We don't have to leave yet. It's very early.
section.sectiontitle2: Don't have to is very different from mustn't. Mustn't means something is not allowed. Don't have to means it isn't necessary.
section.text3: You mustn't smoke in the aeroplane.
section.text3a: You don't have to sleep in the aeroplane.
section.text4: In the zoo, you mustn't throw things at the animals.
section.text4a: You don't have to stay in the zoo all day.

section.title: Modal verbs of obligation and prohibition
section.sectiontitle: Use should to say something is a good idea. Use shouldn't to say something is not a good idea. Use subject + should(n't) + verb infinitive (without to).
section.text1a: You should see that new film. It's very good.
section.text2a: You shouldn't eat too many sweets. They're bad for you.
